headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: China: Affluence Brings Obesity

docs.abstract: China says about 60 million of its citizens are obese, with correspondingly high number of cases of high blood pressure and diabetes; authorities say increase in consumption of high-fat junk food is responsible (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Rising affluence has made about 60 million Chinese, a number equal to the population of France, obese, state media reported. The government-affiliated State Food and Nutrition Consultant Committee said Chinese people are eating more fat and junk food, along with fewer grains and vegetables, leading to a high number of cases of high blood pressure and diabetes. Because of the poor eating habits, according to Ministry of Health statistics, last year 160 million Chinese had high blood pressure in a population of about 1.3 billion, up from 90 million in 1991.

headline.main: Live to Regret Those Calories ... (7 Letters)

docs.abstract: Seven letters comment on obesity crisis in America (Oct 29, Oct 30 and Nov 2 articles and Oct 31 editorial); Elsa Kieken says as long as Americans do not realize there is no miracle for too many calories, they will keep piling on pounds; Ruth Knoblauch says French people are thinner because they are more active; John Harrington says making fast-food restaurants list calories is waste of time; Cory Eisenhard says if New York wants to create health-conscious consumers, it should require fast-food establishments to show stats on saturated and trans fats and sugars; Stephen Helfer suggests taxing foods that contribute to epidemic of obesity; Omar Wing says perhaps simplest way to control obesity is to charge food by weight; Julian Jamison says cause for weight gain is behavior by both individual and society; drawing
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Yes, Red Wine Holds Answer. Check Dosage'' (front page, Nov. 2):
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''Yes, Red Wine Holds Answer. Check Dosage'' (front page, Nov. 2):

docs.lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about a tendency to blame obesity for a range of problems misattributed the journal that published a letter about how much extra fuel airlines use carrying fatter Americans. It was the American Journal of Preventive Medicine, not The American Journal of Public Health. The article also misspelled the name of a Brown University political science professor who commented that the intent of such studies is to persuade the obese to lose weight. He is James Morone, not Marone.

headline.main: A Business Where Customers Grow Along With Sales

docs.lead_paragraph: After dipping for several years beginning in 2000, confectionery sales are climbing.
docs.snippet: After dipping for several years beginning in 2000, confectionery sales are climbing.

docs.abstract: Catherine Duckett letter discusses Holley Mangold, female high school lineman; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor: My husband thinks that a female offensive lineman like Holley Mangold is gross; I think it is great. Thanks for continuing the provocative discussion on the roles and (subtextually) body types of men and women. Catherine Duckett Highland Park, N.J. To the Sports Editor: The article glorifies Holley Mangold, but the facts warrant a warning, not a celebration. Because she is carrying 310 pounds on a 5-foot-9 frame, how long will it be before her knees deteriorate? What is her risk for diabetes?

docs.abstract: Jeneen Interlandi's Oct 22 article on scientific fraud perpetrated by Eric Poehlman prompts letters from Michael Hadjiargyrou and Mary Nelson
docs.lead_paragraph: Jeneen Interlandi's article was fascinating (Oct. 22). The irony is that Walter DeNino, the lab technician who was trained by Eric Poehlman and eventually exposed him for ''fabricating more than a decade's worth of scientific data on obesity, menopause and aging,'' was doing exactly what he was trained to do as a scientist: follow the scientific method and search for the truth. In this capacity, he formulated a hypothesis (Poehlman was fabricating data), performed experiments, analyzed his data (reviewing patients' records and talking to members of Poehlman's lab about concerns about data analyses) and concluded, based on the data, that his hypothesis was indeed correct. As such, DeNino has successfully demonstrated his scientific skills, even if they were used to expose his mentor, who consciously decided to stray from the scientific method for purely selfish reasons. Well done, Mr. DeNino!
